item.title: High Cholesterol Causes: 5 Risk Factors of Excessive LDL Plaque Formation In Heart Arteries - TheHealthSite
item.description:
High Cholesterol Causes: 5 Risk Factors of Excessive LDL Plaque Formation In Heart Arteries

Publication Date: Not specified
Source: The Health Site

The article discusses high cholesterol, particularly high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL), which is a significant risk for cardiovascular health. It outlines the top five risk factors contributing to LDL plaque formation in heart arteries.

Key Points

  • Unhealthy Diet: Diets high in saturated and trans fats can raise LDL levels.
  • Not Exercising Regularly: Sedentary lifestyle increases cholesterol levels.
  • Excessive Weight or Obesity: Obesity correlates with high LDL and lower HDL cholesterol levels.
  • Genetic Contribution: Familial hypercholesterolemia influences cholesterol levels from a young age.
  • Excessive Smoking: Smoking contributes to high cholesterol and reduces HDL.

Notable Quotes

“Regular check-ups and blood tests are essential for monitoring cholesterol.”

Taking control of risk factors can help manage cholesterol and improve heart health.

item.title: Keeping bones healthy in winter: How to maintain bone health during cold months - The Times of India
item.description:
Keeping Bones Healthy in Winter: How to Maintain Bone Health During Cold Months

Publication Date: November 2023
Source: Health News

This article discusses the importance of maintaining bone health during the colder months, providing practical tips and recommendations.

  • Emphasizes the impact of cold weather on bone health.
  • Recommends activities to keep bones strong and healthy.
  • Highlights dietary considerations for bone density.
“Winter can be tough on our bones, but with the right care, we can keep them healthy.”

In conclusion, maintaining bone health in winter is crucial, and by following these tips, individuals can ensure their bones remain strong.

item.title: Flu Virus Found To Survive In Refrigerated Raw Milk: Study - Free Press Journal
item.description:
Flu Virus Found To Survive In Refrigerated Raw Milk: Study

Date: Sunday, December 15, 2024

Source: Free Press Journal

The study conducted by Stanford University reveals that the influenza virus can remain infectious in refrigerated raw milk for up to five days. This raises concerns about the potential health risks associated with raw milk consumption.

  • The flu virus H1N1 PR8 remained infectious in raw milk at refrigeration temperatures.
  • More than 14 million Americans consume raw milk annually despite health risks from pathogens.
  • The FDA links raw milk to over 200 outbreaks of serious illnesses.
  • Pasteurization is effective in destroying infectious influenza but not all viral RNA.
  • Flu viruses infect over 40 million people in the U.S. each year, causing significant health issues.
  • Bird flu detection in cattle raises further concerns about transmission through dairy products.
"The persistence of infectious influenza virus in raw milk for days raises concerns about potential transmission pathways." - Mengyang Zhang

The findings stress the importance of pasteurization and monitoring systems to manage food safety, especially amid ongoing bird flu outbreaks.

item.title: Poliovirus found in wastewater in Spain, Germany and Poland — what you need to know - The Indian Express
item.description:
Poliovirus found in wastewater in Spain, Germany and Poland — what you need to know

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Indian Express

In recent months, traces of poliovirus have been found in wastewater in Germany, Spain, and Poland, signaling potential risks for public health and raising alarms for vaccination coverage across Europe.

  • The WHO initiated a global effort to eradicate polio in 1988, achieving a 99% reduction in cases.
  • Polio is a highly contagious disease that can lead to paralysis and death, primarily spread through the faecal-oral route.
  • Despite significant gains in eradication, two countries, Pakistan and Afghanistan, remain endemic.
  • Detection of poliovirus in wastewater can warn healthcare systems of potential outbreaks.
  • Vaccine-derived poliovirus strains can revert to virulent forms if circulation occurs among under-immunised populations.
“The alert triggered by wastewater surveillance systems in Spain, Poland and Germany highlights how wastewater-based surveillance provides public health authorities with another weapon in the fight against infectious diseases.”

The findings underscore the importance of monitoring vaccination coverage and enhancing public health responses to prevent polio's resurgence.

item.title: Feeling lonely? Study says loneliness increases your risk of developing dementia by 31% - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Feeling lonely? Study says loneliness increases your risk of developing dementia by 31%

Date: Dec 15, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

A groundbreaking study published in Nature Mental Health finds that loneliness increases the risk of developing dementia by 31%. It emphasizes the severe impact of loneliness on brain health.

  • The study analyzed data from 608,561 individuals worldwide.
  • Loneliness was shown to be a crucial risk factor for dementia, comparable to smoking and lack of exercise.
  • Researchers noted loneliness leads to cognitive decline and is linked to Alzheimer’s disease and vascular dementia.
  • Lack of mental stimulation and chronic stress due to loneliness contribute to the risk of dementia.
  • Loneliness can also lead to mild cognitive problems, indicating early effects before dementia onset.
“This is groundbreaking, as the risk factor of loneliness is similar to other commonly known risk factors for dementia.”

This study highlights the urgent need for addressing loneliness as a public health issue, especially in light of its long-term implications for cognitive health.

item.title: Tripura’s treasure: Fermented bamboo shoot emerges as a natural fat-fighter - EastMojo
item.description:
Tripura’s treasure: Fermented bamboo shoot emerges as a natural fat-fighter

Published on: Not specified, Source: Institute of Advanced Study in Science and Technology (IASST)

Researchers from IASST, Guwahati, have discovered the anti-obesity potential of Melye-amiley, a traditional fermented bamboo shoot from Tripura. The research reveals its ability to reduce fat accumulation and promote energy expenditure.

A Tradition Meets Modern Science

Among five studied varieties, Melye-amiley stood out for its significant health benefits, credited to natural fermentation and bioactive compounds.

How It Works: The AMPK Pathway

The study shows how Melye-amiley activates the AMPK pathway, promoting fat breakdown and increasing mitochondrial activity in fat cells.

Natural Compounds Drive Change

GC-MS profiling identified bioactive metabolites in the bamboo shoot extract, with more research needed to isolate those influencing the AMPK pathway.

Traditional Wisdom Backed by Science

“With rising obesity rates worldwide, there is a growing interest in natural dietary interventions that can support weight management.” - Dr. Mojibur R. Khan

A Step Toward Anti-Obesity Therapeutics

Findings may lead to further studies and commercial opportunities for Melye-amiley-based products, although in vivo validation is necessary.

The Road Ahead

The next steps include isolating bioactive compounds and testing their effects on obesity in animal models, with hopes of contributing to health-conscious food products.

item.title: Understanding The Connection Between Quality Sleep And Stroke Risk - TheHealthSite
item.description:
Understanding The Connection Between Quality Sleep And Stroke Risk

Publication Date: N/A Source: The Health Site

With increasing evidence supporting the role of sleep in reducing stroke risk, doctors and patients alike should prioritize sleep as an essential part of stroke prevention strategies. Studies have revealed a direct correlation between sleep quality, duration, and stroke risk.

Key Points

  • Stroke risks: Factors like hypertension, diabetes, and lifestyle issues are well known, but sleep quality is key.
  • Sleeping too little: Fewer than six hours of sleep increases risk factors like blood pressure and obesity.
  • Excessive sleep: Consistently sleeping more than nine hours may also raise stroke risk.
  • Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA): OSA doubles the risk of stroke.
  • Insomnia: Links to inflammation and hypertension further elevate stroke risk.
“One in four people is at risk of experiencing a stroke at some point in their lifetime.”

Understanding how crucial sleep is can aid in stroke prevention strategies and overall health improvement.

item.title: Why Does Winter Worsen Asthma Symptoms—And How Can You Fight Back? - Times Now
item.description:
Why Does Winter Worsen Asthma Symptoms—And How Can You Fight Back?

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Times Now

Asthma sufferers may face heightened challenges during winter due to cold air, indoor allergens, and increased respiratory infections. Dr. Sushrut Ganpule provides insights on managing asthma symptoms effectively during the colder months.

  • Cold, dry air can irritate airways, leading to increased mucus production.
  • Indoor allergens like dust mites and mold spores can exacerbate symptoms.
  • Respiratory infections, particularly during winter, trigger many asthma episodes.
  • Cold and flu medications may worsen symptoms for asthmatics.
  • Important management strategies include staying hydrated, practicing good hygiene, and using a humidifier.
“If you’ve ever gone outside on a cold day and found yourself coughing and short of breath, you’ve felt this firsthand.” - Dr. Sushrut Ganpule

Dr. Ganpule emphasizes carrying an inhaler, obtaining flu vaccines, and ensuring good indoor air quality as key measures for asthma management in winter.

item.title: How intermittent fasting could lead to hair loss - The Indian Express
item.description:
How Intermittent Fasting Could Lead to Hair Loss

Publication Date: December 13, 2023

Source: Cell

Intermittent fasting, a popular weight-loss method, may have unintended effects on hair growth, as a recent study indicates a possible link between the diet and hair loss.

Key Points

  • Intermittent fasting restricts calorie intake to specific hours, often leading to weight loss and improved insulin sensitivity.
  • Despite its benefits, research has revealed potential risks, including an increased risk of death from cardiovascular disease.
  • The recent study found that intermittent fasting may inhibit hair follicle regeneration by causing programmed cell death in stem cells responsible for hair growth.
  • Initial findings from animal trials suggest a slower hair regeneration rate in mice on intermittent fasting diets.
  • Future larger studies are needed, since results may vary among individuals due to the heterogeneous nature of the human population.
“Commonly used intermittent fasting regimens inhibit hair follicle regeneration by selectively inducing apoptosis in activated hair follicle stem cells.”
“During fasting, adipose tissue starts to release free fatty acids, and these fatty acids enter the HFSCs that were recently activated, but these stem cells don’t have the right machinery to use them.” - Bing Zhang, Senior Author

In conclusion, while intermittent fasting may offer weight loss benefits, it is important to consider its potential negative effects on hair growth, necessitating further research for a comprehensive understanding.

item.title: India Achieves Milestone in Malaria Control with 69% Drop in Cases and Deaths: WHO Report - Pratidin Time
item.description:
India Achieves Milestone in Malaria Control with 69% Drop in Cases and Deaths: WHO Report

Publication Date: 2024-12-15 Source: The Publish Live

India has made significant strides in combating malaria, achieving a 69% reduction in both cases and deaths according to the latest WHO report.

  • India officially exited the high burden high incidence (HBHI) group in 2024.
  • Malaria cases decreased from 64 lakh in 2017 to 20 lakh in 2023, a 69% decline.
  • Malaria deaths dropped from 11,100 to 3,500, a 68% decrease.
  • India accounts for half of the malaria cases in Southeast Asia, contributing to 1.5% of the global malaria burden.
  • Between 2000 and 2023, India reduced malaria cases by 82.4%.
  • Community health workers played a crucial role in lowering malaria cases.
  • Globally, malaria deaths remained high, urging greater investments in high-burden countries.
“The WHO report recognized India’s efforts, highlighting the crucial role of community health workers, particularly women...”

India's progress in malaria control showcases a significant public health achievement, albeit with ongoing challenges in the fight against malaria globally.

item.title: Can drinking coffee boost longevity? - Medical News Today
item.description:
Coffee May Help Prolong Lifespan by Almost 2 Years, on Average

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Medical News Today

This article discusses a review study conducted by researchers at the University of Coimbra, which suggests that regular coffee consumption could add an average of 1.8 years of healthy living to a person's life.

  • Coffee is one of the most popular beverages worldwide, with approximately 2 million cups consumed daily.
  • Past studies have debated the health effects of coffee; the new review highlights its potential benefits.
  • Analysis of over 50 studies indicates that regular coffee drinkers might live healthier lives longer.

“Moderate intake of coffee was found to decrease the incidence of several chronic diseases.” – Rodrigo Cunha, PhD

Researchers attribute these benefits to specific compounds in coffee, including antioxidants, that may slow aging processes. The implications suggest coffee could play a crucial role in enhancing the quality of life as populations age.

item.title: Top 5 immunity-boosting drinks for winter - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Top 5 Immunity-Boosting Drinks for Winter

Publication Date: December 13, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

This article explores five delicious drinks that can boost your immunity during the winter season.

  • Turmeric Golden Milk: Warm milk with turmeric, black pepper, and honey, known for its antioxidants and anti-inflammatory properties.
  • Ginger Lemon Tea: A zesty blend of ginger, lemon, and honey, rich in vitamin C and soothing for sore throats.
  • Tulsi and Peppermint Tea: A calming brew that boosts immunity and helps clear nasal congestion.
  • Spiced Apple Cider: A festive drink made by simmering apple juice with cinnamon, cloves, and star anise.
  • Amla and Ginger Juice: Fresh amla juice blended with ginger and honey, high in vitamin C and known for detoxifying properties.
“Vitamin C is essential for immune defense. These drinks can help keep you healthy during the winter.”

Incorporating these immunity-boosting drinks into your winter routine can enhance your health and well-being.

item.title: 5 healthy superfood recipes for your kid visual story - Mint
item.description:
5 Healthy Superfood Recipes for Your Kid

Published on: 15 December, 2024

This article shares five delicious superfood recipes designed to promote health in children.

  • The recipes are tailored for kids' tastes and nutritional needs.
  • Each recipe incorporates various superfoods aimed at improving children's health.
  • Focus on easy preparation to encourage involvement from kids.
  • Highlight the importance of healthy eating habits from a young age.
  • Encourages parents to explore new healthy options for their children's meals.
"Healthy eating in childhood can prevent a plethora of health issues later in life."

Encouraging children to enjoy healthy foods early on can lead to a lifetime of better eating habits.
